Award.AbstractNarration:
Litigation versus Administration, and its Implications for Policy and Democracy

When Congress enacts a law to regulate some facet of economic or social life where compliance is mandatory, it faces a choice between enforcement through bureaucratic machinery and the use of lawsuits, or some combination of the two in a mixed approach. Since the late 1960s, there has been massive growth in the frequency with which Congress has chosen to implement federal regulatory law by allowing and incentivizing private lawsuits. This project investigates whether, when Congress relies upon the actions of litigants and courts for implementation of regulatory statutes, this choice has consequences for the nature of the legislative process leading to passage, and for the subsequent content of those laws.

Given Congress' growing reliance upon litigation and courts for regulatory implementation since the late 1960s, shedding light on this question will offer insight into democratic governance and regulatory procedures.

Since the late 1960s, there has been significant growth in the frequency with which Congress has chosen to implement federal regulatory law by allowing and incentivizing lawsuits, a development that has occurred across the waterfront of federal policy, from environmental, to civil rights, to labor, to consumer protection regulation. This development has been extensively criticized on the ground that it dislocates policymaking authority from the bureaucracy to litigation and courts, a policy implementation venue that is more distant from democratic control and less expert. This project investigates whether, when Congress relies upon litigants and courts for implementation of regulatory statutes, this choice has consequences for the content for the statutes. The literature on regulation provides grounds to predict that Congress, when relying upon litigation and courts for implementation, may write more detailed laws, resolving more policy issues within Congress, and delegating less discretion to implementers. The project created a novel dataset to evaluate whether this proposition, which has not previously been tested, is supported. To the extent that it is supported, it would show that the powerful growth in congressional reliance on litigation since the late 1960s has been associated with an expansion of the congressional role in laying down the details of public policy in the domain of federal regulation. This proposition would be new to analysis of the role of litigation in American government and public policy. To the extent that it is not supported, it would be consistent with the claim that growing reliance upon litigation has been associated with a shift of policymaking power from the administrative state to courts, with no consequence for the congressional role. Given the transformation toward greater congressional reliance upon litigation and courts for regulatory implementation since the late 1960s, shedding light on this question can reveal important consequences of this transformation for the institutional locus of national policymaking. The primary goal of the project is to assess whether greater specificity of regulatory legislation is associated with statutory provision for implementation and enforcement of the legislation via litigation and courts. The project develops an empirical measure of the extent to which Congress resolves issues itself in legislation versus delegating them to be resolved by implementers (judges or bureaucrats). While work on the larger project continues, preliminary analysis of the data created by the project reveals that Congress does, in fact, lay down substantive policy in substantially greater detail when it relies upon lawsuits for implementation and enforcement.
